Hey！I should be asking this in Pluto, but I already did, and no one replied... so I think its worth asking here once！The devs here have some experience with Pluto too, I think！
 
In YaoPlots, when the circuit diagram is long in width, we have a scroll bar to view the entire circuit.
Can I achieve this "scroll bar" with an image too(png or svg or any other format)？

messages.text: Hi there, is there a way to tell Yao that some gates have fixed parameters, so they don't appear in parameters()? My motivation is to avoid calculating grandients with respect to parameters that are fixed in my circuit. My current solution is to define all constant gates via @const_gate, but this is a bit convoluted when the number of constant gates is large

elements.text: Hi there, is there a way to tell Yao that some gates have fixed parameters, so they don't appear in parameters()? My motivation is to avoid calculating grandients with respect to parameters that are fixed in my circuit. My current solution is to define all constant gates via @const_gate, but this is a bit convoluted when the number of constant gates is large

messages.text: Yes, try wrap the block with `NoParam(block)`

elements.text: Yes, try wrap the block with
NoParam(block)

messages.text: Hello! I have one question. Generally we can define gate like parameterized Rx and Controlled Rx in the quantum circuit. I wonder whether we can define gate in the form like time evolution U = exp(-i \theta X1X2) in the circuit?

elements.text: Hello! I have one question. Generally we can define gate like parameterized Rx and Controlled Rx in the quantum circuit. I wonder whether we can define gate in the form like time evolution U = exp(-i \theta X1X2) in the circuit?

messages.text: I haven't find docs introducing this gates so far

messages.text: hello, based on discussion above, I wonder whether we can define quantum gate like this u=exp[-i \theta (x1x2+y1y2)], and also, how can I optimize circuits including this kind of gate?

elements.text: hello, based on discussion above, I wonder whether we can define quantum gate like this u=exp[-i \theta (x1x2+y1y2)], and also, how can I optimize circuits including this kind of gate?

messages.text:
No, you can not define the above gates as a rotation gate, instead, you should define it as a time evolution operator.
```julia> using Yao

julia> h = kron(X, X) + kron(Y, Y)
nqubits: 2
+
├─ kron
│  ├─ 1=>X
│  └─ 2=>X
└─ kron
   ├─ 1=>Y
   └─ 2=>Y

julia> time_evolve(h, 0.7)
Time Evolution Δt = 0.7, tol = 1.0e-7
+
├─ kron
│  ├─ 1=>X
│  └─ 2=>X
└─ kron
   ├─ 1=>Y
   └─ 2=>Y


julia> rot(h, 0.5)
ERROR: ArgumentError: Gate type Add{2} is not hermitian or not isreflexive.
Stacktrace:
 [1] RotationGate at /home/leo/.julia/dev/YaoBlocks/src/primitive/rotation_gate.jl:20 [inlined]
 [2] RotationGate at /home/leo/.julia/dev/YaoBlocks/src/primitive/rotation_gate.jl:26 [inlined]
 [3] rot(::Add{2}, ::Float64) at /home/leo/.julia/dev/YaoBlocks/src/primitive/rotation_gate.jl:79
 [4] top-level scope at REPL[5]:1 ```
This is because the rotation gate requires the hamiltonian being reflexive (i.e. h^2 == 1).

elements.text: No, you can not define the above gates as a rotation gate, instead, you should define it as a time evolution operator.

julia> using Yao

julia> h = kron(X, X) + kron(Y, Y)
nqubits: 2
+
├─ kron
│  ├─ 1=>X
│  └─ 2=>X
└─ kron
   ├─ 1=>Y
   └─ 2=>Y

julia> time_evolve(h, 0.7)
Time Evolution Δt = 0.7, tol = 1.0e-7
+
├─ kron
│  ├─ 1=>X
│  └─ 2=>X
└─ kron
   ├─ 1=>Y
   └─ 2=>Y


julia> rot(h, 0.5)
ERROR: ArgumentError: Gate type Add{2} is not hermitian or not isreflexive.
Stacktrace:
 [1] RotationGate at /home/leo/.julia/dev/YaoBlocks/src/primitive/rotation_gate.jl:20 [inlined]
 [2] RotationGate at /home/leo/.julia/dev/YaoBlocks/src/primitive/rotation_gate.jl:26 [inlined]
 [3] rot(::Add{2}, ::Float64) at /home/leo/.julia/dev/YaoBlocks/src/primitive/rotation_gate.jl:79
 [4] top-level scope at REPL[5]:1
This is because the rotation gate requires the hamiltonian being reflexive (i.e. h^2 == 1).

messages.text: Is `measure_remove!()` being deprecated ?

elements.text: Is
measure_remove!()
being deprecated ?

messages.text: If yes, is there any alternative to the above function? I think its quite useful

elements.text: If yes, is there any alternative to the above function? I think its quite useful

messages.text:
There is an alternative
```julia> reg = rand_state(5)
ArrayReg{1, Complex{Float64}, Array...}
    active qubits: 5/5

julia> measure!(ResetTo(bit"00111"), reg)
01001 ₍₂₎

julia> measure!(RemoveMeasured(), reg)
01001 ₍₂₎

julia> reg
ArrayReg{1, Complex{Float64}, Array...}
    active qubits: 0/0```

elements.text: There is an alternative

julia> reg = rand_state(5)
ArrayReg{1, Complex{Float64}, Array...}
    active qubits: 5/5

julia> measure!(ResetTo(bit"00111"), reg)
01001 ₍₂₎

julia> measure!(RemoveMeasured(), reg)
01001 ₍₂₎

julia> reg
ArrayReg{1, Complex{Float64}, Array...}
    active qubits: 0/0

messages.text:
Hi everyone!
Using expect' to get the gradient of a parametric circuit that contains a UnitaryChannel Block results in the following error:
```MethodError: no method matching mat_back!(::Type{Complex{Float64}}, ::UnitaryChannel{1,StatsBase.Weights{Float64,Float64,Array{Float64,1}}}, ::Array{Complex{Float64},2}, ::Array{Any,1})```
Is this a known problem? (I'm pretty new with Yao so it might totally be my fault :sweat_smile:)

elements.text:
Hi everyone!
Using expect' to get the gradient of a parametric circuit that contains a UnitaryChannel Block results in the following error:
MethodError: no method matching mat_back!(::Type{Complex{Float64}}, ::UnitaryChannel{1,StatsBase.Weights{Float64,Float64,Array{Float64,1}}}, ::Array{Complex{Float64},2}, ::Array{Any,1})
Is this a known problem? (I'm pretty new with Yao so it might totally be my fault

messages.text: This is not your fault, this is because the adjoint rule for this block has not been implemented in Yao.

elements.text: This is not your fault, this is because the adjoint rule for this block has not been implemented in Yao.

messages.text: It is not trivial to implement the adjoint rule for a unitary channel, because it is probablistic.

elements.text: It is not trivial to implement the adjoint rule for a unitary channel, because it is probablistic.

messages.text:
hi everyone
Using `expect'` to get the gradients of a batched parametric circuit seems not work, is there any detail I have missed?
```reg = focus!(addbits!(copy(x_batch_yao),1) |> circuit, (nbit+1)) |> CuYao.cpu
pauli_z = Array{Complex{Float64}}([1 0;0 -1])
expect'(matblock(pauli_z),reg)```
resulting in following result but not those gradients
```ArrayReg{10, Complex{Float64}, Array...}
    active qubits: 1/9```

messages.text:
hi everyone, I wonder how to unroll the gradient of batched data?
when I use `expect'` to compute the gradient of a batch of data, it always returns the sum of gradients of each data, how to get those gradients of each data respectively?

elements.text:
hi everyone, I wonder how to unroll the gradient of batched data?
when I use
expect'
to compute the gradient of a batch of data, it always returns the sum of gradients of each data, how to get those gradients of each data respectively?

messages.text: I think you have to turn the batch into a for loop. You do not need to worry about the performance for number of qubits > 15, because the performance of batched and non-batched versions are similar at this scale.

elements.text: I think you have to turn the batch into a for loop. You do not need to worry about the performance for number of qubits > 15, because the performance of batched and non-batched versions are similar at this scale.
